transcripts.text: Even back during the 2016 presidential primaries, there were serious calls for a Joe Biden run.  Without declaring his candidacy, he ranked in both second and third place in the polls before announcing that he would not be running.  Having lost his son Beau Biden to brain cancer in May of 2015, Joe was not emotionally prepared to jump into the race early on.  In October, he announced that he would not be running.

As my family and I have worked through the grieving process, I've said all along that it may very well be that that process, by the time we get through it, closes the window on mounting a realistic campaign for president.  I've concluded it has closed.

While he assessed that it was too late to run then, polling indicates that 2016 may have been too early, since Joe Biden's support looks even stronger today.  In poll after poll, Biden's prospects for 2020 look stronger than any other potential or declared Democratic candidate.  He is shown to be the top choice in all but five of the last 30 polls on the topic tracked by FiveThirtyEight.com.  Two of those five were ties, which included Biden.  Real clear politics shows a similar pattern, with Biden leading in all of the last 13 polls, with an average spread of 20.5 points.  Unlike Clinton in 2016, or Trump then and now, Biden is also extremely well-liked throughout the country.  In every popularity poll RCP has collected since August of 2018, Biden has a positive spread.  In the last five polls, his net favorability has been plus 17, plus 21, plus 30, plus 32, and plus 24 points, respectively.  Popular throughout the country and the top dog when it comes to Democratic support, Biden appears to be the strongest contender for the Democratic primary, with a strong chance of beating Trump in the general, at least for now.  While Biden undoubtedly appears to be a very strong candidate for the Dems, I count at least five potential issues that his campaign will likely face if he were to throw his hat into the ring.  I'll leave it to you to let me know what you think of Biden in the comments section.  But with his popularity as high as it is, I'll attempt to answer the question, what could stop him?  Currently, Joe Biden is probably best known as the former vice president who might have won in 2016, but did not because of a family tragedy.  The idea that he lost his chance to run because of the passing of his son no doubt draws personal sympathy.  Once he becomes a real contender for the most powerful office in the land, that sympathy might take a backseat to the day-to-day business of the primary process.  The reality is that Joe Biden has been out of the political spotlight since 2016, and for eight years prior to that, he was in the spotlight, but in a position that doesn't exactly draw serious scrutiny.
The vice presidency is a mostly symbolic job.

Unlike Dick Cheney, Biden was a fairly typical VP, who mostly played the role of Obama's mascot.  This has been a particularly beneficial situation for Joe since Obama, by some measures, is even more popular than he is.  While the January 2019 Harvard-Harris poll found that 56% of Americans have a favorable opinion of Biden, Obama is favored by 59%.  A previous Harvard-Harris survey found that the most common self-identification of Democratic voters was Obama Democrat, a label more popular than liberal Democrat, moderate Democrat, or environmentalist.  Embarking on his own presidential campaign will mean being judged on his own merits, by his own platform, his own words, and his own capabilities.  And if history is any judge, Biden is not particularly good at running for president.  Like breaking up, running for president is hard to do.  Hillary Clinton, an extremely well-known Democrat, tried twice and failed both times.  I don't think I need to argue the point that there is no real interest in seeing Clinton run in 2020 or ever again.  Even CNN's Chris Colizza argued that she should not give it another go.  Democrats should be rooting very hard against another presidential bid by Clinton.  Joe Biden has also had two failed runs.  So why should Biden get a third chance if Clinton shouldn't?  Well, to be fair, Clinton's history differs from Biden's.  In her second run, she won the Democratic primary and went on to lose to a historically unpopular GOP candidate.  In Biden's case, his second loss was to an extremely popular Democratic candidate who would go on to select him as his running mate and win two terms with that same ticket.  Let's be honest, for Democrats, it's clearly more favorable to lose to a Democrat and go on to beat Republicans than it is to beat out Democrats and then lose to a Republican.  Still, being a two-time loser does not exactly bode well for Biden.  It is itself an issue, but nevertheless one that I expect is not insurmountable.  Far more problematic are some of the reasons behind his past losses.  One of those is his long history of gas.  Biden has been long known as a sufferer of foot and mouth disease.  Here are some of his most famous gaffes.

If we do everything right, we do it with absolute certainty.  We stand up there and we make really tough decisions. In Delaware, the largest growth in population is Indian Americans moving from India.  You cannot go to a 7-Eleven or a Dunkin' Donuts unless you have a slight Indian accent.  I'm not joking.  Chuck Graham, state senator's here.  Chuck, stand up.  Chuck, good to see you.  Oh, God love you.  What am I talking about?  I tell you what, you're making everybody else stand up, though, pal.  I mean, you got the first sort of mainstream African-American who is articulate and bright and.

Now, it may be the case that Trump has had a number of gaffes himself, so one could argue that this issue is washed.  At the same time, Trump has shown remarkably stable albeit low approval ratings throughout his presidency, indicating that his base of support shows strong loyalty regardless of what the president says.
They say, I have the most loyal people.  Did you ever see that?  Where I could stand in the middle of Fifth Avenue and shoot somebody and I wouldn't lose any voters, okay?  It's like incredible.
Trump seems to be somewhat inoculated from minor scandals, perhaps because he has groomed his base to be especially distrusting of what he calls fake news.
Just stick with us.  Don't believe the crap you see from these people, the fake news.
There is little to suggest that Biden supporters will be equally distrusting of the news media.
It just doesn't work that way.

If he gaffes, as he is prone to do, the media is likely to report on what he says, as they have in the past, and voters are likely to be turned off as a result, as they have been in the past.  Biden is likely to run into trouble when he doesn't choose his words carefully.  But potentially even more problematic for Joe is the fact that he has a long history of choosing words that aren't his own.  Joe Biden's plagiarism dates back as far as his time in law school.  As the New York Times reported during his first run for president in 1987, Senator Joseph R. Biden  Jr.,  fighting to salvage his presidential campaign, today acknowledged a mistake in his youth when he plagiarized a law review article for a paper he wrote in his first year at law school.  Mr.  Biden insisted, however, that he had done nothing malevolent, that he had simply misunderstood the need to cite sources carefully.  The plagiarized article, Tortious Acts as a Basis for Jurisdiction in Products Liability Cases, was published in the Fordham Law Review of May 1965.  Mr.  Biden drew large chunks of heavy legal prose directly from it, including such sentences as, "...the trend of judicial opinion in various jurisdictions has been that the breach of an implied warranty of fitness..." is actionable without privity because it is a tortious wrong upon which suit may be brought by a non-contradicting party.  Biden plagiarized so blatantly that he actually defended his plagiarism to school administrators by pointing out how obvious the plagiarism was, arguing that if he was doing it on purpose, why would he be so blatant?  His explanation was accepted, and he was allowed to repeat the course, earning a B. Sadly, Biden's plagiarism did not end when he graduated law school.  In fact, the New York Times actually reported on his plagiarism in school because of another growing plagiarism scandal then facing his presidential campaign.  In another article from 1987, the Times reported, At the Democratic National Convention in 1976, Hubert Humphrey, then a senator from Minnesota, declared, The ultimate moral test of any government is the manner in which it treats three groups of its citizens.  First, those who are in the dawn of life are children.  Second, those who are in the shadows of life are sick, are needy, are handicapped.  and those third in the twilight of life are elderly.  Senator Biden's version offered a nation noble enough to treat those at the dawn of life with love, those at the dusk of life with care, and those who live in the shadow of life with compassion.  Biden did not acknowledge that he was paraphrasing Humphrey, and this was by no means the only speech he stole from.  Here he is extensively plagiarizing British MP Neil Kinnock.

And I started thinking as I was coming over here, why is it that Joe Biden is the first in his family ever to go to a university? Why is it that my wife, who's sitting out there in the audience, is the first in her family to ever go to college?  Because they were weak.

Weak.  My ancestors who worked in the coal mines in northeast Pennsylvania and then come up after 12 hours and play football for four hours.

Now you'd think going across the pond to find someone to plagiarize might indicate that he was really learning to be less obvious.  But he plagiarized from some big names in America too.  Here's him taking words from Bobby Kennedy.
But this standard is not a measure of how we can evaluate the condition of our society.  cannot measure the health of our children, the quality of our education, the joy of their play.

The notion that every thought or notion or idea you'd have to go back and find and attribute to someone, I think is quite frankly ludicrous.

Unlike his law school, however, the media and the American people did not let him off the hook.  He ended his campaign on September 23rd, 1987, essentially blaming the media for elevating the significance of the scandal.
I made some mistakes.  But now the exaggerated shadow of those mistakes has begun to obscure the essence of my candidacy and the essence of Joe Biden.

In today's media landscape, there is very good chance that Biden will have to answer for his past indiscretions all over again.  New media has the capacity to dig up old problems, and it can also create new ones.  One of them is the creepy Uncle Joe meme.  One of Donald Trump's most effective campaign tools seems to be his ability to give political enemies catchy juvenile nicknames, like Crooked Hillary, Lion Ted, Pocahontas, and Little Marco.  When it comes to Biden, Trump's work has already been done for him.  He basically just needs to AB test Creepy Uncle Joe against Creepy Joe Biden, and he's sure to come up with a winner for his supporters.  You may have seen images like this, or like this.  These are actually both manipulated images.  Here are the real ones.  Photoshopped images of Joe Biden are by no means a reason that he shouldn't run or should expect not to do well in a 2020 campaign.  But while Biden has not, as far as we've seen, groped women as he has falsely depicted as doing in these images, the creepy Joe thing doesn't come from nowhere.  He has had a history of being a little too familiar and handsy with women and girls.
trust and confidence.  I've got a lot of thanks to give out here.  First and foremost to my perfect wife, Stephanie.  Thank you.

Given the strength of Joe's current poll numbers, it's hard to expect that any of these issues would totally derail his campaign.  But if I were one of his campaign advisors, I'd take a hard look at his overly affectionate conduct, plagiarism, and gaffes, and ask the question, what could stop him?
